reviewText:
Take the Dream IX is probably not a game for everyone.
On the surface it follows the story of the protagonist Gwen
trying to save her love Flora. Throughout the game though
things get more and more surreal and you start wondering
what this is actually all about.

The aspect of horror was is nicely put into the scene
by creating an atmosphere that makes you feel uneasy.
But not only that, the game also has some comedic
elements to it.With it's constant change of atmosphere
and a bit of mysterieit deffinitly keeps you interessted in
what's going to happen next.

The puzzles in the game are not too easy and not too hard,
even though you might have to retry some of them
several times.
Also the game has nicely written dialouge
and interessting characters.

All in all in my oppinion it is a good game with it's
own charm and quirks.
Though I wouldn't recomment this to everyone, due
to it being a game with a focus and experiencing it,
rather than playing. But I deffinitly recomment it
to anyone who likes to experience a game and is
a fan of surrealism.

reviewText:
This is a game that, in no light terms, keeps you on your toes.

[Light spoilers may follow, skip ahead for the summary if you wish to avoid these.]

Take the Dream IX dresses itself as a run of the mill RPG Maker title, but it doesn't revel in this disguise for long. Although it won't take long to find the surreal, horrific world underneath, Take the Dream IX never forgets its premise. Genre savvy players will appreciate both the lightly satirical and the dark, serious takes on the common tropes of top down RPGs.

Functionally, this game is similar to Yai Gamework's previous title Close Your Eyes". The player controls a central protagonist to inspect various objects throughout the world
date: and solve the occasional puzzle. There is no(?) combat.\n\nThe puzzles can feel rough around the edges at times
recommended: but on completion and inspection are designed intuitively. The difficulty of the puzzles is nicely balanced; you won't find yourself stuck for hours
hoursPlayed: but it will take a little brain power to get through.\n\nThe main attraction of Take the Dream IX though
voteText: is the oddly compelling story. On the surface you have a generic main plot of "I must save my love!" This is satisfyingly both played straight at times
helpfulPercent: then twisted and subverted at others. The world you venture through is surreal in a way you won't quite be able to put your finger on. This is easily the biggest draw pushing you forward
votesHelpful: to see what comes next. Like I mentioned above
votesTotal: you won't want for surprises during your journey.\n\nThe game takes roughly 2 hours to complete
votesFunny: and I would recommend finishing it in one session. There are no loud or cheap jumpscares
commentsCount:
so you can turn the volume up without fear.


In summary

column19: with writing that invokes a pointed feeling of empathy in the player. Those of us who played Close Your Eyes will find some pleasant surprises within. The game is also free and fairly small
column20: so you can try it out with little hassle. I whole heartedly recommend you do so
column21: as you aren't likely to forget this one soon."

reviewText:
[no story spoilers but some gameplay ones]

Take the Dream IX is a quirky game that has a lot of things going on, which can be rather confusing initially. It starts off as generic as possible, but it's fairly obvious that this is deceptive if you've seen the marketing for it. (The only way you would actually think it was a traditional generic RPG is if you went in 100% blind.) It doesn't take long to establish that something is amiss in the world, and the game does a great job at building a sense of unease and subverting expectations right when you thought you knew what was coming next. At times it feels like a traditional horror game, other times it feels like pure parody. While I personally enjoyed it, I feel like that aspect could be off-putting and frustrating to people playing.

There are a handful of puzzles throughout the game, many of which I found clever and a good balance of difficulty. The only puzzle that I felt was a bit mindless was the chemical puzzle in the last timed section, which really seemed more like a time waster than anything else. At the very least, knowing the solution made that part go by very quickly, but it was a strange disconnect from the rest of that area, which was all movement and maze based. Another part I found frustrating was avoiding the Sloppy Joes while the stick figures were in the way, as the random movements basically just made it an annoyance. At least the Sloppy Joes are merciful enough not to kill you and just warp you back to a previous section. (What even are the Sloppy Joes anyway? Their existance is so strange to me.)

Some areas that particularly stood out to me were the clock song puzzle and the dark area where you're trying not to get spotted. I played it last night before the latest patch, so I'm not sure how much the puzzle changed, but I thought it was interesting and made me think without needed to resort to trial and error. The stealth area felt the most like a horror game to me because the monsters are unsettling and I felt very on edge during the whole segment, and it was intense trying to avoid being spotted, especially when you don't really know their range of vision. (I somehow managed to get through without dying once, though I was playing it VERY safe until the end.)

Another point about the game is that it's VERY meta, almost a bit too meta for it's own good. I don't want to spoil too many story points, but it's a very Ryan" game. If you're familiar with him and his works you'll understand what I mean when you play it. Expect to see some subtle (and not so subtle) references to his previous Steam game "Close Your Eyes." You don't need to have played that game to enjoy this one
date: however. It is very much a standalone story.\n\nI guess the part I'm most conflicted about is the ending
hoursPlayed: given the information revealed in the story
voteText: I'm not really sure how I would have ended it either. Still
helpfulPercent: there is at least some sense of closure
votesHelpful: even if it feels like there's more unanswered questions than answered ones. Overall though
votesTotal: I enjoyed my time playing this game
votesFunny: and would recommend it to anyone who enjoys quirky indie games. It's free and a relatively short game
commentsCount: it took me about three hours
column16: so it'll be well worth your time."

reviewText:
A promising aspiration of the horror genre that ultimately ends in hair-ripping frustration due to oversights in puzzle design. This game surprised me for its hilarious, loveable dialogue, cute characters and well thought-out puzzles up until the timed puzzle, which I'll get into later.

You play Gwen, who describes herself as a tomboy, who is in love with another girl called Flora. But this game isn't your typical love story or yuri, as the amusing ArKun villain is introduced, sets the tone for the rest of the game. You're now on a journey to save your girlfriend by going through very creative areas, set pieces, changes of pace and atmosphere at the click of a finger, and puzzle designs that took me back to the days of the old PlayStation 2 survival horror games such as Silent Hill 2, 3 and 4. The puzzle involving the animal heads was genuinely well-made, perhaps one of the best puzzles I've experienced in a horror game since Silent Hill 4.

The hand-drawn art is awesome, it fits the aesthetics of the game and is always a pleasure to look at. However, I would have preferred better transition effects from sprite-to-artwork, such as screen fades or something. Also, the scene near the beginning of the game where Flora is looking out over the cliff could have been enhanced with her hair blowing in the wind, to give it a dramatic effect. This also ties in with how much this game feels like a JRPG despite it being made by an American. As mentioned, the dialogue is surprisingly filled with comedic value - which doesn't detract from the game's enjoyment - but adds to it as it supports the style the game is aiming to achieve. You have lots of different characters, whom I all love, some have their own artwork which gives them even more character through visual narrative.

For a free game this is amazing, there is so much variety in this short-packed adventure, such as the Sloppy Joes, dark atmosphere of the underground crypts, to your everyday Highschool life. However, and this is where I can't recommend this game, is one of the final puzzles in this game. It is the segment that you dive into a lava pit with a timer and have to escape by solving the chemical puzzle, then traversing through the maze-like structure to avoid the lava, then become swarmed by double digit Sloppy Joes (who are the enemies in this game). This is incredibly frustrating, it feels too forced and pressuring to have this come out of nowhere, and it will try your patience as a human being. You either don't have enough time to finish this segment, don't have enough health to beat it due to forced damage, either too many Sloppy Joes swarm you at once, or the horribly unforgiving checkpoint system will make you want to jump our your window. A recent patch was deployed which was suppose to alleviate this infuriating design; but changed little to nothing. So if you're reading this and want to play this, be warned this puzzle will test you.

That said, for owners of Yai Gamesworks' previous game: Close Your Eyes, there is an awesome throwback moment to it, which I really loved and found funny. I won't spoil, but you'll get a giggle out of it for sure.

I can't recommend this game, however, because the instant rise of difficulty killed the game's tone, pacing and comedy value it had going for it. This kind of frustration and experimental puzzle design doesn't always work, and when it does it's usually added in a type of game that has this kind of trial and error persistent in its design. The Souls games, for example, is a mainstream series that glorifies this structured gameplay style. But in an adventure game such as this, where its value comes from the story and puzzles, stopping the player from continuing due to its own design is this game's only downfall. The developer clearly knows what they are doing in this game and, can for a fact, make good puzzles and atmospheric set pieces, but experimenting on abnormal design tradition to further the progression of what is a light comedy, adventurous game is not a mix that bodes well together. Perhaps a future patch can fix this, but I'm not willing to put up with furious design choices out of nowhere, especially after the disaster of a game that is NightCry. But with Take the Dream IX, there is clearly hope and light at the end of the tunnel that Yai Gameworks knows how to make great games.

And no, there is no Take the Dream I-VIII.

reviewText:
I really enjoy AestheticGamer's approach to horror - and, without spoilers - some great satire on the current state of gaming in Take the Dream IX.  I felt genuinely interested in the characters, and throughly enjoyed the different themes laced through the gameplay.  Yes, this was a rougher, more experimental game, but I feel that sometimes those are the best!  Nothing is gained without sometimes just throwing things at the wall until they stick, and the atmosphere and mood created a great sense of dread in certain points of the game that I found engrossing.

Addressing one of the elephants in the room:  There is a particular section of the game that is a bit difficult.  It took me about 8 - 10 attempts to clear it, and I could see people (myself included) raging a bit about it.  I think I have  very clear idea about what the creator was trying to do here, and it made especially more sense upon the next part of the game.

Let's just say, it's a satire of a particular style of game - one that tends to get a lot of coverage through certain social media channels.  I tip my bonnet to you sir.

Anywho, overall a very unique and enjoyable horror / comedy / tragedy / satire experience.  I will continue to look forward to future games by Yai Gameworks!

reviewText:
Take the dream IX is a 2D horror game made with RPG Maker.

You play as the girl gwen" thats about to go to a festival where she met here true love 1 year ago at the same festival. (She is lesbian so its a girl yes). The girl she is in love with is called Flora. At the start you search for Flora in your home town but can't find her. Then you go to a cliff with a beatifull view where you see here looking at the view. You get in a conversation with her. Eventually she wants to ask you something and it goes like this. "Gwen this may be a silly question but i want you to answer it seriously". Gwen is like "Sure". Then she starts with "I....i... was wondering etc. But then out of no where a random ghost/ghoul comes and takes Flora. Your journey continues where you will find many obstacles and challenges you need to pass to save flora (and mind♥♥♥♥s ;3).

-Take a very good look at the story line because if you look back it all fits togheter beatifull-

I kinda hate horror games and I didn't know that this was one

reviewText: Not quite a horror like Close Your Eyes, but is still a somewhat sequel (You should play CYE first) The game is still made by the same dev, however, and so is still pretty unnerving. I guess the best way to compare this game is kind of like Pan's Labyrinth, being unnerving and a masterpiece but with horror like  elements. The story is all over the place, but that is intentional. This game also has both a lot of symbolism and faux symbolism. Also, The Host! But still, despite the dev worrying that this would be the worst recieved of his games, it still is wonderful and sets the bar for future games like Red Haze. He wanted to create something different, and he seems to have done that! The game is genre savvy, and a pleasant surprise, especially for those who play other rpg maker games, Yai Gameworks games, or horror or romance games. Hey, its free, its made by a good developer and lets player, and its not your average free-ware rpg maker game. Play it. That is all.

reviewText: Take the Dream IX is a pretty neat surreal adventure RPG that I found myself enjoying. The biggest surprise to me was that from the moment I started playing I somehow recognized it was from the same devs that made Close Your Eyes http://store.steampowered.com/app/377330/  I did not think it had left an impression on me but I remembered it right away when I heard the voice acting and started moving around.  Thats when I realized I was now a fan of Yai Gameworks games. I am looking forward to trying Red Haze now as well! http://store.steampowered.com/app/428860/\n\nI wont go into much plot stuff here but I love the approach to horror in a sort of surreal way the devs take, I liked Take the Dream IX and if you liked Close your Eyes, are a fan of indie horror games, or just looking for a free to play game to try I would recommend Take the Dream IX to that exact niche of player.

While i wouldn't go as far as to call it a horror game there was a a good number of jumps and surprises that was made it all the better with the amazing sound tracks and effects. Only thing that i wish was a little different was the last level the time limit really stressed how fast you should go and the test in the middle just took away time i could have used to manuver around sloppy joe. reviewText:
This is more of a survival horror game than a actual RPG game. It was made with RPG Maker sure. But you only fight one battle in the entire game and only level up once. The game leaves a lot of questions unanswered and the ending is kind of lack luster too.

That said for what it was it was a decent game. I really wanted a happy ending, didn't get that. I wanted to be able to go on an epic quest. That didn't happen either.

The game in it's entirety is only about 2 hours long.

I can't either recommend or not recommend because everyone has different tastes.

reviewText:
This follow up to Close Your Eyes is terrific.

In this game, you play as Gwen, a villager in a small happy town. You're on your way to meet your girlfriend, Flora, when... things happen. To say much more would be to give away a lot of the story.

All you really need to know is that, like Close Your Eyes, this is a truly bizarre, creepy, and sometimes even funny game that balances a lot of tones really well. It packs in a lot of variety during it's two hour play time, with lots of puzzles and surprises. Sometimes it's cute, sometimes it's funny, and sometimes it's flat out freaky, but the one constant is it is never boring.

My one complaint is a segment near the end that is timed. Despite the kick ♥♥♥ song that plays, it's really repetitive, tough, stressful, and tedious if you die in it, where you have to start all the way at the beginning of the challenge. It took me several tries and was imply not enjoyable.

Despite that one flaw, this is another confusing but engaging horror game from the makers of the excelent Close Your Eyes. It's got unique visuals, a weird but engaging story, real atmosphere that sucks you in, and anawesome soundtrack. Great job, devs, and really looking forward to Red Haze and Close Your Eyes 2.

So, download it. It's free! Show these creative people that unique ideas are things to be celebrated. Download Close Your Eyes while you're at it.

reviewText:
*This review contains no spoilers*

Let me start by saying that this game is awesome and was really fun to play.

Now then, that doesn't mean it doesn't have it's kinks; Take the Dream IX" has plenty of them. For instance the "Sloppy Joe" enemy has a really odd hit box that isn't too forgiving when interacting with the movement speed of Gwen (the main character) or the fast-er pace of Sloppy Joe - meaning that there are some odd waiting times and sketchy doges that occur in the game to be able to avoid taking hits from this type of enemy. Additionionally some of the sequences and obstacles (like stickmen running amuck or lava pools that I found to be hard to avoid with the semi-slow response on the controls) take away from the beautiful art style/areas and breaks the seemlessness of the game.

The story itself is a bit confusing too. Personally

reviewText: 4/10\nThe presentation was solid; many of the graphical choices added to the creepy atmosphere and overall the sound design was solid. The puzzles and challenges are fun but are too few. The story really holds the game back, I appreciate what the developer was trying to accomplish, making attempts to mess with the player's head. But mind-bending games only work if the early-game confusion is balanced out either by endgame understanding, or a very clear theme and message. This game offers neither, and when I finished I felt the game was too short and did not work hard enough to explain what was happening.

reviewText: I would not recomend this game as-is, but I really hope the game designer continues to work on it; there is potential here.\n\nFor a game about how desperately one may cling to love, this game as it is now feels simply devoid of heart and meaning. Its silly use of tropes and unprofessional sounds/voices really take you out of the story. I hope the designer keeps trying, because there is a balance between meaningful and fun that can be struck here, and I think some more editing, tweaking, re-scripting the lines, and re-recording the voices would help make this an unforgettable jaunty adventure with a dark twist.

hoursPlayed: Luna and I don't even remember the last one). So all the dialogue between them end up being pointless melodrama that only got in the way to the game.\nNothing was really explained at the end.\nAlso
voteText: what was the point of starting the game with the story of a Goddess and a Demon King and a bunch of magic stones if this will be barely used in the game? Really
votesHelpful:
finishing with "it was only a dream" made me feel like that were some 2 wasted hours that I could have used to something more fun and productive.

---END OF SPOILER ALERT---

The game would be ok

I think there is a bug where you are in that purple map after the palace scene, and you go down the hallway and nothing happened, I've walked down the hallway for more than 10 times.

At the beginning the story was fine but when you go deep the story get awkward and messy.
The music and the demon king's voice were annoying.
